issue.title: Low frame rates on sensors with 1.8.6/2.6.5

content.raw:
Checking on @faller 's constellation machines, starting with sim:

~~~
ubuntu@sim-03:~$ rostopic hz /sandia_hands/r_hand/camera/left/image_raw
subscribed to [/sandia_hands/r_hand/camera/left/image_raw]
average rate: 30.100
        min: 0.032s max: 0.034s std dev: 0.00053s window: 19
average rate: 30.050
        min: 0.032s max: 0.034s std dev: 0.00061s window: 37
~~~
~~~
ubuntu@sim-03:~$ rostopic hz /multisense_sl/laser/scan -w 20
subscribed to [/multisense_sl/laser/scan]
average rate: 40.000
        min: 0.024s max: 0.026s std dev: 0.00046s window: 20
average rate: 40.000
        min: 0.024s max: 0.026s std dev: 0.00032s window: 20
~~~

And fc1:
~~~
ubuntu@fc1-03:~$ rostopic hz /sandia_hands/r_hand/camera/left/image_raw
subscribed to [/sandia_hands/r_hand/camera/left/image_raw]
average rate: 30.050
        min: 0.032s max: 0.034s std dev: 0.00056s window: 19
average rate: 30.008
        min: 0.032s max: 0.035s std dev: 0.00062s window: 38
~~~
~~~
ubuntu@fc1-03:~$ rostopic hz /multisense_sl/laser/scan -w 20
subscribed to [/multisense_sl/laser/scan]
average rate: 40.000
        min: 0.025s max: 0.025s std dev: 0.00000s window: 20
average rate: 40.000
        min: 0.025s max: 0.025s std dev: 0.00000s window: 20
~~~

And fc2:
~~~
ubuntu@fc2-03:~$ rostopic hz /sandia_hands/r_hand/camera/left/image_raw
subscribed to [/sandia_hands/r_hand/camera/left/image_raw]
average rate: 31.405
        min: 0.007s max: 0.035s std dev: 0.00593s window: 20
average rate: 30.705
        min: 0.007s max: 0.035s std dev: 0.00434s window: 38
~~~
~~~
ubuntu@fc2-03:~$ rostopic hz /multisense_sl/laser/scan -w 20
subscribed to [/multisense_sl/laser/scan]
average rate: 40.000
        min: 0.024s max: 0.026s std dev: 0.00046s window: 20
average rate: 40.000
        min: 0.025s max: 0.025s std dev: 0.00000s window: 20
~~~

That all looks correct to me.

issue.title: Low frame rates on sensors with 1.8.6/2.6.5
Low frame rates on sensors with 1.8.6/2.6.5

content.raw:
Can you please do all three commands at the same time:

* rostopic hz /sandia_hands/r_hand/camera/left/image_raw

* rostopic hz /multisense_sl/laser/scan

* rostopic hz /multisense_sl/camera/left/image_raw

Gazebo doesnt generate the sensor data if there are no subscriptions. For each subscription the speed will slow down a bit.

So when we subscribe to all the cameras, we end up at 10Hz across the board.

@jespersmith : do you see the same issue?
content.html:
Can you please do all three commands at the same time:

  • rostopic hz /sandia_hands/r_hand/camera/left/image_raw

  • rostopic hz /multisense_sl/laser/scan

  • rostopic hz /multisense_sl/camera/left/image_raw

Gazebo doesnt generate the sensor data if there are no subscriptions. For each subscription the speed will slow down a bit.

So when we subscribe to all the cameras, we end up at 10Hz across the board.

@jespersmith : do you see the same issue?

issue.title: Low frame rates on sensors with 1.8.6/2.6.5
Low frame rates on sensors with 1.8.6/2.6.5

content.raw:
As a datapoint,  I am running on one of the SL machines.

Starting `vrc_task_1.launch`, without moving the robot, simply
~~~
rostopic hz /multisense_sl/laser/scan
rostopic hz /multisense_sl/camera/left/image_raw
~~~
produces 40Hz scan and 30Hz camera images as expected.  But if also subscribing to hand camera at the same time:
~~~
rostopic hz /sandia_hands/r_hand/camera/left/image_raw
~~~
All three topics drop to 25Hz.

Further, by subscribing to the left Sandia hand camera
~~~
rostopic hz /sandia_hands/l_hand/camera/left/image_raw
~~~
All GPU sensor rates drop to 15Hz.
content.html:
As a datapoint, I am running on one of the SL machines.

Starting vrc_task_1.launch, without moving the robot, simply

rostopic hz /multisense_sl/laser/scan
rostopic hz /multisense_sl/camera/left/image_raw

produces 40Hz scan and 30Hz camera images as expected. But if also subscribing to hand camera at the same time:

rostopic hz /sandia_hands/r_hand/camera/left/image_raw

All three topics drop to 25Hz.

Further, by subscribing to the left Sandia hand camera

rostopic hz /sandia_hands/l_hand/camera/left/image_raw

All GPU sensor rates drop to 15Hz.

issue.title: Low frame rates on sensors with 1.8.6/2.6.5

content.raw:
I got the same rates as @scpeters and @hsu.

I believe the bottleneck is in transferring data from gpu to memory every time an image need to be published, as previous profiling has shown that this call is expensive.
content.html:
I got the same rates as @scpeters and @hsu.

I believe the bottleneck is in transferring data from gpu to memory every time an image need to be published, as previous profiling has shown that this call is expensive.

issue.title: Low frame rates on sensors with 1.8.6/2.6.5

content.raw:
Shouldnt the simulator block till all data is available?

Gazebo is probably doing it already, but we have seen performance issues copying data over in our own sim, a big improvement was seen after switching to double buffered pbos instead of glreadpixels, but it is still expensive.
content.html:
Shouldnt the simulator block till all data is available?

Gazebo is probably doing it already, but we have seen performance issues copying data over in our own sim, a big improvement was seen after switching to double buffered pbos instead of glreadpixels, but it is still expensive.

issue.title: Low frame rates on sensors with 1.8.6/2.6.5

content.raw: @scpeters  and @hsu : this bug wasn't evident in the previous version of drcsim/gazebo that we used to test on the cloud machines last week.
content.html: @scpeters and @hsu : this bug wasn't evident in the previous version of drcsim/gazebo that we used to test on the cloud machines last week.

issue.title: Low frame rates on sensors with 1.8.6/2.6.5

content.raw:
You mean blocking the whole physics simulation? I don't think that's feasible for us because an important goal is to achieve a high real time factor.

Unfortunately ogre still uses glreadpixels, and we're limited by this underlying rendering engine. Not long ago I tried to implement ways around this (issue #[688](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issue/688/gpu-based-sensor-update-rates-throttled-by)), but that did not show promising improvement and it complicated the code. Instead, a different sensor strategy was used to help increase framerate.
content.html:
You mean blocking the whole physics simulation? I don't think that's feasible for us because an important goal is to achieve a high real time factor.

Unfortunately ogre still uses glreadpixels, and we're limited by this underlying rendering engine. Not long ago I tried to implement ways around this (issue #688), but that did not show promising improvement and it complicated the code. Instead, a different sensor strategy was used to help increase framerate.

issue.title: Low frame rates on sensors with 1.8.6/2.6.5

content.raw:
I see the hz rate slowly drop on my desktop with subscriptions to one camera and laser.

With all four cameras and lasers, I get 15Hz for all cameras, 25Hz for the laser.

 At first blush, it seems like the camera's can't keep up with physics. Slowing down physics (increase iters, or decrease real_time_update_rate) has the effect of increasing the sensor frame rate. For example, a physics update rate of 200 produces correct Hz rates, but the real-time-factor is now 0.20.
content.html:
I see the hz rate slowly drop on my desktop with subscriptions to one camera and laser.

With all four cameras and lasers, I get 15Hz for all cameras, 25Hz for the laser.

At first blush, it seems like the camera's can't keep up with physics. Slowing down physics (increase iters, or decrease real_time_update_rate) has the effect of increasing the sensor frame rate. For example, a physics update rate of 200 produces correct Hz rates, but the real-time-factor is now 0.20.

content.html:
@iche033 Yeah, I was proposing blocking the whole simulation as this is the easiest solution that shouldn't affect anyone much.

Correct simulation of physics/sensors is more important than realtime in my opinion. We haven't seen much of this slowdown, as we only subscribed to left eye and lidar.

We just started using a subscription on the right eye, so this might pose a small problem for us.

issue.title: Low frame rates on sensors with 1.8.6/2.6.5

content.raw: The left and right eyes are rendered together, i.e. if you subscribe to the left eye, the right eye sensor is also activated at the same time.  I just tested on SL and subscribing to both left and right eyes, and the laser scan does not appear to slow down each of the publication rates.
content.html: The left and right eyes are rendered together, i.e. if you subscribe to the left eye, the right eye sensor is also activated at the same time. I just tested on SL and subscribing to both left and right eyes, and the laser scan does not appear to slow down each of the publication rates.

issue.title: Low frame rates on sensors with 1.8.6/2.6.5
Low frame rates on sensors with 1.8.6/2.6.5

content.raw:
The following two Test Cases take place on softlayer machines using the following steps:

1) Sim: `roslaunch atlas_utils vrc_task_1.launch gzname:=gzserver`

2) Sim: `roslaunch atlas_utils ros_subscribers.launch`

3) FC1: `rostopic hz /multisense_sl/camera/left/image_raw -w 20`

4) FC1: `rostopic hz /multisense_sl/laser/scan -w 20`

5) FC1: `rostopic hz /sandia_hands/r_hand/camera/left/image_raw -w 20`

6) FC1: `rostopic hz /sandia_hands/l_hand/camera/left/image_raw -w 20`

7) Let simulation run for 300 seconds

8) Measure Hz rate of sensor topics.


**Test Case 1**

Gazebo: 1.8.2

DRCSim: 2.6.3

Result: ~11.5 Hz for all sensor topics

Real time factor: 0.70

**Test Case 2**

Gazebo: 1.8.2

DRCSim: 2.6.3

Result: ~12.5 Hz for all sensor topics

Real Time Factor: 0.70

**Conclusion**

Sensor update rates have remained the same since the beginning of practice. Is there something that I'm not running during this test? Did anyone have higher frame rates during practice when subscribed to all the sensors? If so, can you please describe how you achieved those higher frame rates?
content.html:
The following two Test Cases take place on softlayer machines using the following steps:

1) Sim: roslaunch atlas_utils vrc_task_1.launch gzname:=gzserver

2) Sim: roslaunch atlas_utils ros_subscribers.launch

3) FC1: rostopic hz /multisense_sl/camera/left/image_raw -w 20

4) FC1: rostopic hz /multisense_sl/laser/scan -w 20

5) FC1: rostopic hz /sandia_hands/r_hand/camera/left/image_raw -w 20

6) FC1: rostopic hz /sandia_hands/l_hand/camera/left/image_raw -w 20

7) Let simulation run for 300 seconds

8) Measure Hz rate of sensor topics.

Test Case 1

Gazebo: 1.8.2

DRCSim: 2.6.3

Result: ~11.5 Hz for all sensor topics

Real time factor: 0.70

Test Case 2

Gazebo: 1.8.2

DRCSim: 2.6.3

Result: ~12.5 Hz for all sensor topics

Real Time Factor: 0.70

Conclusion

Sensor update rates have remained the same since the beginning of practice. Is there something that I'm not running during this test? Did anyone have higher frame rates during practice when subscribed to all the sensors? If so, can you please describe how you achieved those higher frame rates?

issue.title: Low frame rates on sensors with 1.8.6/2.6.5

content.raw:
I have (non-ROS) logs that show 40Hz lidar consistently during practice. For testing purposes we slowed down our cloud simulator during practice for diagnostics - that might be the missing piece.
The issue seems to be a function of the rate of simulation: when it goes above ~0.3 the sensors start dropping back of the defined rates.

We also added in use of the hand cameras recently - drawing more sensor data (i.e. twice as much).

40Hz lidar is essential for our approach.
content.html:
I have (non-ROS) logs that show 40Hz lidar consistently during practice. For testing purposes we slowed down our cloud simulator during practice for diagnostics - that might be the missing piece. The issue seems to be a function of the rate of simulation: when it goes above ~0.3 the sensors start dropping back of the defined rates.

We also added in use of the hand cameras recently - drawing more sensor data (i.e. twice as much).

40Hz lidar is essential for our approach.

issue.title: Low frame rates on sensors with 1.8.6/2.6.5

content.raw:
@hsu : Yes. I request 5Hz multisense using /multisense/set_fps so thats always at 5Hz max. I re-transmitt left and right at 5Hz with our own message passing mechanism.

There's no such mechanism for the sandia hand cameras on my laptop 
rostopic hz  /sandia_hands/r_hand/camera/right/image_raw
gives 30Hz.
But again I retransmit at 5Hz - but 30 is generated by gazebo.

We could probably go lower but I'd have to check with team members.
content.html:
@hsu : Yes. I request 5Hz multisense using /multisense/set_fps so thats always at 5Hz max. I re-transmitt left and right at 5Hz with our own message passing mechanism.

There's no such mechanism for the sandia hand cameras on my laptop rostopic hz /sandia_hands/r_hand/camera/right/image_raw gives 30Hz. But again I retransmit at 5Hz - but 30 is generated by gazebo.

We could probably go lower but I'd have to check with team members.

issue.title: Low frame rates on sensors with 1.8.6/2.6.5

content.raw:
I don't think that there's much to be done about this issue at this point.

The GPU-based sensors have to queue for access to the GPU to do rendering.  Activating more sensors puts more in that queue and you'll eventually be rate-limited by access to the GPU.

The current behavior has been in place since we [switched the MultiSense-SL laser to use the GPU](#!/osrf/drcsim/pull-request/254/gazebo_ros_gpu_laser_plugin-for-default/diff), first released in [drcsim 2.6.0 on May 17th](http://gazebosim.org/wiki/DRC/Change_log#drcsim_2.6.0_.282013-05-17.29).

It's unfortunate that you're just encountering this behavior now.  It hadn't occurred to us that a team would practice with simulation slowed down.
content.html:
I don't think that there's much to be done about this issue at this point.

The GPU-based sensors have to queue for access to the GPU to do rendering. Activating more sensors puts more in that queue and you'll eventually be rate-limited by access to the GPU.

The current behavior has been in place since we switched the MultiSense-SL laser to use the GPU, first released in drcsim 2.6.0 on May 17th.

It's unfortunate that you're just encountering this behavior now. It hadn't occurred to us that a team would practice with simulation slowed down.

issue.title: Low frame rates on sensors with 1.8.6/2.6.5

content.raw:
If the cloud computers are not fast enough to render the cameras and lidar real time, I still think that slowing down the simulation is the only realistic choice. Most, if not all teams, are used to running less than realtime on development machines.

That said, we do not have any issues with the topic speed, it really does not matter for us if we loose a few lidar scans here and there. To practise with our controller & gazebo in real time, we would have needed two cloud-spec machines per developer.
content.html:
If the cloud computers are not fast enough to render the cameras and lidar real time, I still think that slowing down the simulation is the only realistic choice. Most, if not all teams, are used to running less than realtime on development machines.

That said, we do not have any issues with the topic speed, it really does not matter for us if we loose a few lidar scans here and there. To practise with our controller & gazebo in real time, we would have needed two cloud-spec machines per developer.

issue.title: Low frame rates on sensors with 1.8.6/2.6.5

content.raw: There is nothing we can do to fix this in time for the VRC. Teams will have to choose wisely what sensors to use and not use.
content.html: There is nothing we can do to fix this in time for the VRC. Teams will have to choose wisely what sensors to use and not use.

issue.title: Low frame rates on sensors with 1.8.6/2.6.5

content.html:
@gerkey : The hand cameras are generated at 30Hz and there is no way to request them at lower rates. I did ask on May 16th. What about generating these at lower rates? It would only be a matter of changing the urdf for the hands.

The laser generates very little data relative to the cameras and we only need the cameras a low rates.

And as Jesper said, we could only have run at realtime if we could give every teammember 3 expensive desktops. We use both fc1 and fc2.

issue.title: Low frame rates on sensors with 1.8.6/2.6.5

content.html:
@faller : You're right that it's easy to change sensor update rates in the URDF to slow down some cameras in deference to the laser. But for all we know, other teams are counting on high update rates from those cameras. In this case, where there's no free lunch, we have to be conservative and leave the system how it's been since the start of practice.

You've surely already thought of this, but: a workaround is to actively manage your subscriptions to sensors that use the GPU. E.g., in general only subscribe to cameras when you need them, and specifically when you need high-rate data from the laser, unsubscribe from cameras that you don't strictly need.

Down the road, it would be good to support subscriber-configurable sensor update rates to allow users to make these tradeoffs more easily at runtime.
